resource.publisher: Open Data Commons for Spinal Cord Injury (ODC-SCI)

rightsList.rights: Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Public License

descriptions.description: STUDY PURPOSE: The purpose of this study is to discover, through high throughput methods, blood RNA biomarkers with the ability to diagnose accurately the severity of the spinal cord injury at the acute stage. DATA COLLECTED: Total RNA was collected from white blood cells of 38 spinal cord injury patients, 10 healthy subjects and 10 non-CNS trauma patients. The samples were collected on average within the first 24 hours after injury. Subsequently the RNA was used for RNAseq. These subjects were enrolled in the TRACK-SCI clinical study and in addition to the transcriptomic data we collected more than 22,000 data points for each one during their hospitalization. Both clinical and transcriptomic data were used to generate a predictive model for the initial severity of spinal cord injury. PRIMARY CONCLUSION: Analysis of our gene expression data revealed 197 genes that they are expressed in an severity-dependent manner. Furthermore, unsupervised gene co-expression network analysis was used for the discovery of 16 gene modules that are induced upon spinal cord injury. A logistic regression model using these modules displayed high accuracy in diagnosing the initial injury severity.

fundingReference.funderIdentifier: UCSF SCI Center of Excellence special project award (M.S.B.)
